Introduction

Extremity trauma can be either blunt or penetrating, involving injuries that affect bones, muscles, vessels, and nerves.  Complications include as ischemia, infection, nerve damage, and potential loss of limb function.  Blunt trauma can cause fractures, soft tissue injuries, and compartment syndrome, whereas penetrating trauma may result in direct damage to vital structures such as blood vessels and nerves.

Upper extremity anatomy

Major vascular structures

Axillary, brachial, radial, and ulnar arteries (

figure 1
).

Major nerves

  • Brachial plexus:  a network of nerves (
    figure 2
    ) originating from the spinal cord (C5-T1) that provides motor and sensory innervation to the shoulder, arm, and hand.  It divides into 5 major peripheral nerves: the axillary, musculocutaneous, radial, median, and ulnar nerves.
  • Axillary nerve (
    figure 3
    ):  innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, allowing shoulder abduction and external rotation.  Provides sensation to the skin over the lateral shoulder (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (
    figure 5
    ):  controls elbow flexion by innervating the biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles.  Provides sensation to the lateral forearm (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Radial nerve (
    figure 7
    ):  controls extension of the elbow (triceps), wrist, and fingers, and assists in forearm supination.  Provides sensation to the posterior arm, forearm, and back of the hand, including the thumb, index, and middle fingers (
    figure 8
    ).
  • Median nerve (
    figure 9
    ):  controls most of the muscles responsible for flexing the wrist and fingers (flexor muscles), as well as thumb opposition (thenar muscles).  Supplies sensation to the palmar side of the thumb, index, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger (
    figure 10
    ).
  • Ulnar nerve (
    figure 11
    ):  innervates muscles that control fine movements in the hand (intrinsic hand muscles), as well as wrist and finger flexion on the ulnar side.  Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal surfaces of the little finger and medial half of the ring finger (
    figure 12
    ).

Skeletal/muscular structures

Bony structures in the arm include the humerus, radius, and ulna.  Major muscles include the biceps (

figure 13
), triceps (
figure 14
), forearm flexors, and extensors.

Lower extremity anatomy

Major vascular structures

Femoral, popliteal, tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries (

figure 15
).

Major nerves

  • Femoral nerve (
    figure 16
    ):  innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, including the quadriceps femoris (extends the knee joint).  Supplies sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • Sciatic nerve (
    figure 17
    ):  splits into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves, aids in knee flexion.  Supplies sensation to the posterior thigh, posterior leg, and most of the foot.
  • Deep peroneal nerve (
    figure 18
    ):  innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, including the tibialis anterior and peroneal muscles (which dorsiflex the ankle and extend the toes).  Supplies sensation to the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Tibial nerve (
    figure 19
    ):  innervates the posterior compartment of the leg, including the gastrocnemius, soleus, and muscles of the foot.  Provides sensation to the sole of the foot and the posterior calf.

Skeletal/muscular structures

Bony structures in the lower extremity include the femur, tibia, fibula, and patella.  Major muscles in the lower extremity include the following (

figure 20
):

  • Quadriceps muscles (rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, vastus intermedius)
  • Hamstrings (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus)
  • Calf muscles (gastrocnemius, soleus, tibialis anterior and posterior, fibularis longus and brevis, flexor and extensor digitorum longus, flexor and extensor hallucis longus)

Clinical presentation and evaluation

Extrema trauma can cause injuries to the vessels, muscles, bones, and nerves.  Clinical presentation and subsequent evaluation will depend on what structures are injured.

Vascular injuries

  • Findings
    • "Hard signs":
      • Observed pulsatile bleeding
      • Presence of a bruit or thrill over the injury
      • Expanding hematoma
      • Signs of distal ischemia (eg, absent pulses, cool extremities)
    • "Soft signs":  Diminished pulses, history of significant hemorrhage, bony injury, neurologic abnormality
  • Implications for further evaluation
    • Patients with hard signs should generally be taken for immediate surgical exploration.
    • Patients without hard signs should have further diagnostic evaluation:
      • Injured extremity index (IEI):  The IEI is analogous to the ankle-brachial index (ABI) (
        figure 21
        ) but can apply to any extremity.  It is indicated for any patient with suspected vascular injury but without obvious hard signs (eg, diminished but present pulses, small hematomas).  The IEI is the ratio of the highest systolic occlusion pressure in the injured extremity at the level of the dorsalis pedis/posterior tibial (or radial/ulnar arteries) divided by the systolic pressure in a proximal vessel in an uninjured extremity (eg, brachial artery).  An IEI â‰¤0.9 is abnormal (
        ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
        ) and indicates the need for further vascular imaging.
      • CT angiography (CTA):  The gold standard for evaluating vascular injuries.  CTA is indicated when "soft signs" are present, IEI is abnormal (eg, â‰¤0.9), or there is suspicion of arterial involvement based on examination or history (eg, high-velocity projectile near major vessels).  Conventional arteriography can also be used but is invasive and more time consuming.
      • Duplex ultrasonography:  Can be used to evaluate specific vascular injuries (eg, pseudoaneurysms, arteriovenous fistulas) when CTA is unavailable or contraindicated.

Musculoskeletal injuries

  • Findings
    • Obvious deformity, instability, or crepitus may indicate a fracture or dislocation.
    • Limited range of motion or inability to bear weight can suggest muscle injury, tendon rupture, or fracture.
    • Open wounds over a fractured bone are concerning for open fractures (occur when bone penetrates the skin, exposing the fracture site to the external environment).
  • Implications for further evaluation:  Any physical examination abnormality suggestive of a fracture, dislocation, or foreign body (eg, bullet) warrants plain x-rays.  X-rays should typically include the joint above and below the suspected injury.

Neurologic injuries

  • Findings
    • Motor weakness or complete paralysis in certain muscle groups can indicate nerve injury (eg, wrist drop with radial nerve damage, foot drop with peroneal nerve injury).
    • Sensory loss in specific dermatomes or loss of reflexes.
  • Implications for further evaluation:  When neurologic deficits are present on physical examination, further evaluation is indicated.  Depending on the specific deficit, this may require imaging (eg, spine imaging), consultation with a specialist (eg, hand surgeon), or monitoring for improvement (particularly true in blunt trauma).  Given that many nerves run with vascular structures, vascular injury should also be considered and carefully evaluated.

Traumatic amputation

  • Findings
    • Complete severing of a limb or appendage, often accompanied by severe bleeding.
    • Surrounding tissue may show signs of crush injury, ischemia, or contamination, increasing the risk of infection or poor healing.
  • Implications for further evaluation:  Imaging of the stump and amputated part (if replantation possible) is typically obtained.  If the patient is a candidate for replantation, transfer to an appropriate institution should occur.

Compartment syndrome

  • Findings (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    )
    • Early signs:
      • Pain out of proportion to the injury
      • Pain with passive stretch of muscles
      • Tense, swollen compartments
      • Paresthesias
    • Late signs:
      • Decreased sensation
      • Weakness, paralysis
      • Decreased distal pulses
  • Implications for further evaluation:  Any clinical suspicion of compartment syndrome warrants immediate surgical consultation to evaluate the need for fasciotomies (in unclear cases, compartment pressures may be measured).  Compartment syndrome is discussed in more detail in another article.

Management

Hemorrhage control

  • Direct pressure:  primary method of controlling active bleeding (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ).  Apply over the wound immediately.
  • Tourniquets:  should be applied for uncontrolled hemorrhage or exsanguination.  Use proximal to the injury but remove as soon as bleeding is controlled to avoid prolonged ischemia.
  • Resuscitation:  Intravenous fluids or blood products should be administered based on hemodynamic status.  Damage control resuscitation (DCR) is often used in patients with significant hemorrhage.  The goal of DCR is to rapidly control hemorrhage while minimizing the potential for complications associated with massive hemorrhage and coagulopathy (achieved by limiting crystalloid use, transfusing appropriate ratio of blood products early, and managing temperature).

Vascular injuries

  • Unstable patients:  should be taken immediately to the operating room for repair.
  • Hard signs present:  Immediate surgical exploration (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ) is required for hard signs of vascular injury (eg, pulsatile hemorrhage, expanding hematoma, absent pulses).
  • Soft signs present:  CTA and IEI should be performed.  If significant vascular injury is confirmed (eg, arterial occlusion, transection), surgical intervention with repair (eg, vascular grafting or ligation) is indicated.

Musculoskeletal injuries

  • Open fractures:  Immediate (eg, within hours) debridement and irrigation are necessary.  Surgical stabilization (eg, external or internal fixation) is required, and broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated to prevent infection.
  • Closed fractures:  Displaced fractures should be reduced (ie, realigned) and immobilized immediately.  When surgery is indicated, the timing of surgical repair will depend on the type and location of the fracture.
  • Joint dislocations:  Dislocations should be reduced as quickly as possible to limit further injury to the skin (eg, tissue necrosis due to pressure can convert a closed injury to an open injury), nerves, and vascular structures.  Dislocations causing neurovascular compromise should be reduced immediately (do not wait for imaging).
  • Tendon injuries:  Tendon repair should be performed if lacerations are identified, with physical therapy initiated postoperatively to restore function.

Neurologic injuries

  • Motor and sensory deficits:  Management depends on the patient's overall clinical status, severity of the injury, and specific nerve involved.  Complete transection (ie, neurotmesis) of a nerve will require surgical repair.  In general, outcomes are better if the nerve is repaired promptly (eg, within 24-72 hrs).  Patients with neuropraxia (impairment of nerve function without structural damage to the nerve fibers) or axonotmesis (nerve injury that affects the nerve fibers but not the connective tissue), which are more common with blunt than penetrating trauma, may recover spontaneously.  Regular examinations to monitor improvement are recommended followed by delayed repair if symptoms do not resolve.

Traumatic amputation

  • Care of the amputated part:  The amputated part should be wrapped in sterile, saline-moistened gauze and sealed in a plastic bag.  The bag should be then placed in a container of ice water to be transported with the patient (cooling of the amputated part decreases tissue metabolism and oxygen demand, thereby minimizing ischemic damage and prolonging the window of viability for replantation).
  • Replantation:  When replantation is indicated, it should occur as quickly as possible;  delays reduce the likelihood of success.  Replantation is more common in the upper extremity (particularly the digits) than in the lower extremity.

Compartment syndrome

  • Emergency fasciotomy:  Surgical release of the involved compartments should be performed immediately to decompress compartments and restore perfusion.  Delays will cause long-term neurovascular injury and may even result in an amputation.

Complications

  • Ischemia:  Vascular injuries that are not addressed in a timely manner can lead to distal ischemia, requiring amputation.
  • Compartment syndrome:  Failure to recognize and treat this condition can result in permanent muscle and nerve damage or loss of limb.
  • Infection:  Open fractures and soft tissue injuries, especially those associated with foreign body contamination, carry a high risk of infection, including osteomyelitis.
  • Nerve injury:  Delayed nerve repair can result in chronic motor or sensory deficits, which may be permanent.
  • Deep venous thrombosis:  a leading cause of mortality in patients with major trauma.  Patients with extremity trauma (particularly lower extremity trauma) are at significantly increased risk.  Thromboprophylaxis should be considered.
  • Phantom limb pain:  occurs when a patient perceives pain in an amputated body part.  The pain can vary in intensity and can be difficult to manage (pain is thought to arise from the brain and spinal cord's continued response to nerve signals from the missing limb).
  • Posttraumatic neuromas:  a painful, tangled mass of unmyelinated nerve endings that develops over weeks to months after amputation.  The diagnosis is clinical, confirmed by temporary pain relief from local anesthetics.  Treatment involves neuroma excision or pain management (eg, tricyclic antidepressants, antiepileptics).

Summary

Evaluation of extremity trauma requires a structured, systematic approach to identify and manage vascular, musculoskeletal, and neurologic injuries.  Management of severe extremity trauma focuses on controlling hemorrhage, assessing the neurovascular status, and performing appropriate imaging.  For vascular trauma, the presence of hard signs typically necessitates immediate surgical exploration and repair, whereas soft signs indicate the need for further diagnostic evaluation (eg, CT angiography, injured extremity index).  Fractures and dislocations should be promptly reduced and immobilized to avoid further injury; this should be followed by timely surgical repair (when indicated) to prevent long-term disability.  Early recognition and intervention, supported by diagnostic tools such as x-rays, injured extremity index, and CTA, are required to optimize outcomes and prevent complications such as ischemia, nerve damage, and infection.
